Polar bears are uniquely adapted to the Arctic environment, and their strategies for keeping warm are optimized for extremely cold temperatures. It is unlikely that they would be able to survive in warmer climates using these same strategies alone. 

For example, if the climate became too warm, their thick fur and blubber might actually become a disadvantage, causing them to overheat. They could also face additional challenges related to finding food and adapting to new predators and habitats.

In fact, as climate change continues to warm the planet, polar bears are facing increasing threats to their survival due to the loss of arctic sea ice, which is critical to their hunting and breeding behaviors. Unless measures are taken to address the causes of climate change, polar bears could face extinction in the coming decades.
